message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right leg and foot, which can be a complication of hemodialysis. The laboratory findings suggest a low platelet count, which may be indicative of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). The next best diagnostic step would be a heparin/PF4 enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) to confirm the diagnosis of HIT, and to guide changes to anticoagulation therapy. Options B, C, and D are not relevant to the diagnosis of DVT or HIT in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (swelling, erythema) and laboratory findings of thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) and high bilirubin. These are all indicative of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), a serious adverse reaction to heparin therapy. The best diagnostic step is to perform an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) to detect antibodies to heparin-PF4 complexes in the patient's serum. This test has high sensitivity and specificity for diagnosing HIT. The other options listed are not appropriate for diagnosing HIT. Flow cytometry for CD55 is used to diagnose paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, while functional assay for factor VIII and serotonin release assay are used to diagnose other bleeding disorders.
